standard_metadata.standard_description: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Area and perimeter on the coordinate plane

question.content: The upper-left coordinates on a rectangle are $(-1,7)$, and the upper-right coordinates are $(4,7)$.  The rectangle has an area of $20$ square units.    **Draw the rectangle on the coordinate plane below.**

hints.content: Let's draw the two coordinates we know:   [[☃ image 1]]  What is the distance between the two points?

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 1 unit to the left of and 7 units up from the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the left of and 7 units up from the origin.

hints.content: The distance between the points is $\greenD5$ units.     [[☃ image 1]]  Let's use this information to find the width.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 1 unit to the left of and 7 units up from the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the left of and 7 units up from the origin. A line connects the 2 points indicating that the two points are 5 units apart.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \greenD{\text{length}} \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 20&= \greenD5 \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 20\div\greenD5&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ \purpleD4&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \end{align}$  The rectangle has a width of $\purpleD4$ units.
Now we can draw the lower-right and lower-left coordinates $\purpleD4$ units below the existing coordinates:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. The rectangle has vertices at (negative 1, 7), (4, 7), (4, 3), and (negative 1, 3). The rectangle has a base of 5 units. The rectangle has a height of 4 units.

question.content: The upper-left coordinates on a rectangle are $(-6,0)$, and the upper-right coordinates are $(-4,0)$.  The rectangle has an area of $12$ square units.    **Draw the rectangle on the coordinate plane below.**

hints.content: Let's draw the two coordinates we know:   [[☃ image 1]]  What is the distance between the two points?

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 6 units to the left of the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the left of the origin.

hints.content: The distance between the points is $\greenD2$ units.     [[☃ image 1]]  Let's use this information to find the width.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 6 units to the left of the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the left of the origin. A line connects the 2 points indicating that the two points are 2 units apart.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \greenD{\text{length}} \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 12&= \greenD2 \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 12\div\greenD2&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ \purpleD6&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \end{align}$  The rectangle has a width of $\purpleD6$ units.
Now we can draw the lower-right and lower-left coordinates $\purpleD6$ units below the existing coordinates:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. The rectangle has vertices at (negative 6, 0), (negative 4, 0), (negative 4, negative 6), and (negative 6, negative 6). The rectangle has a base of 2 units. The rectangle has a height of 6 units.

hints.content: The distance between the points is $\greenD4$ units.     [[☃ image 1]]  Let's use this information to find the width.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 3 units to the right of and 3 units down from the origin. A solid point is 7 units to the right of and 3 units down from the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the left of the origin. A line connects the 2 points indicating that the two points are 4 units apart.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \greenD{\text{length}} \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 16&= \greenD4 \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 16\div\greenD4&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ \purpleD4&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \end{align}$  The rectangle has a width of $\purpleD4$ units.
Now we can draw the lower-right and lower-left coordinates $\purpleD4$ units below the existing coordinates:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. The rectangle has vertices at (3, negative 3), (7, negative 3), (3, negative 7), and (7, negative 7). The rectangle has a base of 4 units. The rectangle has a height of 4 units.

A solid point is 4 units to the right of and 4 units up from the origin. A line connects the 2 points indicating that the two points are 8 units apart.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \greenD{\text{length}} \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 8&= \greenD8 \times \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ 8\div\greenD8&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \\\\ \purpleD1&=  \purpleD{\text{width}}  \end{align}$  The rectangle has a width of $\purpleD1$ units.
Now we can draw the lower-right and lower-left coordinates $\purpleD1$ units below the existing coordinates:   [[☃ image 1]]

question.content: The upper-left coordinates on a rectangle are $(-4,4)$, and the upper-right coordinates are $(4,4)$.  The rectangle has a perimeter of $20$ units.    **Draw the rectangle on the coordinate plane below.**

hints.content: Let's draw the two coordinates we know:    [[☃ image 1]]  What is the distance between the two points?

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 4 units to the left of and 4 units up from the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the right of and 4 units up from the origin.

hints.content: The distance between the points is $\greenD8$ units.      [[☃ image 1]]  The opposite side of the rectangle will also be $\greenD8$ units.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. A solid point is 4 units to the left of and 4 units up from the origin. A solid point is 4 units to the right of and 4 units up from the origin. A line connects the 2 points indicating that the two points are 8 units apart.

hints.content: Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.   If we subtract the $2$ sides we know from the total perimeter, we will know the length of the missing sides.  $20 - \greenD8 - \greenD8 = \purpleD4$  The missing sides have a combined length of $\purpleD4$ units. We can divide to find the length of each side.  $\dfrac{\purpleD{4}}{2} = \blueD2$  Each missing side will be $\blueD2$ units.
Now we can draw the lower-right and lower-left coordinates $\blueD2$ units below the existing coordinates:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. The rectangle has vertices at (negative 4, 4), (4, 4), (4, 2), and (negative 4, 2). The rectangle has a base of 8 units. The rectangle has a height of 2 units.

hints.content: Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.   If we subtract the $2$ sides we know from the total perimeter, we will know the length of the missing sides.  $16 - \greenD3 - \greenD3 = \purpleD{10}$  The missing sides have a combined length of $\purpleD{10}$ units. question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(5, 1),$ $B(7,1)$, $C(7, 6)$, and $D(5, 6)$.    **What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**   units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (5, 1). Vertex B is at (7, 1). Vertex C is at (7, 6). Vertex D is at (5, 6).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{5},\blueD{ 1})$ and $B(\greenD{7}, \blueD{1})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{7}-\greenD{5}&=2\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.  Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{5},\blueD{ 1})$ and $D(\greenD{5}, \blueD{6})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{6}-\blueD{1}&=5\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $5$ units.  Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $5$ units
Now we can find the perimeter.  Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.  $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  2+2+5+5 \\\\ \phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 14 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $14$ units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(-6, -4),$ $B(-4,-4)$, $C(-4, -2)$, and $D(-6, -2)$.    **What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**   units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (negative 6, negative 4). Vertex B is at (negative 4, negative 4). Vertex C is at (negative 4, negative 2). Vertex D is at (negative 6, negative 2).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{-6},\blueD{-4})$ and $B(\greenD{-4}, \blueD{-4})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{-4}-\left(\greenD{-6}\right)&=2\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.  Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-6},\blueD{-4})$ and $D(\greenD{-6}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{-2}-\left(\blueD{-4}\right)&=2\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $2$ units.  Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $2$ units
Now we can find the perimeter.  Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.  $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  2+2+2+2 \\\\ \phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 8 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $8$ units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(2, -6),$ $B(5, -6)$, $C(5, -2)$, and $D(2, -2)$.    **What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**   units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (2, negative 6). Vertex B is at (5, negative 6). Vertex C is at (5, negative 2). Vertex D is at (2, negative 2).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-6})$ and $B(\greenD{5}, \blueD{-6})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{5}-\greenD{2}&=3\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $3$ units.  Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $3$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-6})$ and $D(\greenD{2}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{-2}-\left(\blueD{-6}\right)&=4\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $4$ units.  Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $4$ units
Now we can find the perimeter.  Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.  $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  3+3+4+4 \\\\ \phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 14 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $14$ units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(2, -3),$ $B(4, -3)$, $C(4, 5)$, and $D(2, 5)$.    **What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**   units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (2, negative 3). Vertex B is at (4, negative 3). Vertex C is at (4, 5). Vertex D is at (2, 5).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-3})$ and $B(\greenD{4}, \blueD{-3})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{4}-\greenD{2}&=2\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.  Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-3})$ and $D(\greenD{2}, \blueD{5})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{5}-\left(\blueD{-3}\right)&=8\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $8$ units.  Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $8$ units
Now we can find the perimeter.  Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.  $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  2+2+8+8 \\\\ \phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 20 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $20$ units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(-2, 1),$ $B(3, 1)$, $C(3, 4)$, and $D(-2, 4)$.    **What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**   units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (negative 2, 1). Vertex B is at (3, 1). Vertex C is at (3, 4). Vertex D is at (negative 2, 4).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{1})$ and $B(\greenD{3}, \blueD{1})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{3}-\left(\greenD{-2}\right)&=5\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $5$ units.  Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $5$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{1})$ and $D(\greenD{-2}, \blueD{4})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{4}-\blueD{1}&=3\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $3$ units.  Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $3$ units
Now we can find the perimeter.  Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.  $\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  5+5+3+3 \\\\ \phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 16 \end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $16$ units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(2, 0)$, $B(6, 0)$, $C(6, 7)$, and $D(2, 7)$.    **What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**   square units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (2, 0). Vertex B is at (6, 0). Vertex C is at (6, 7). Vertex D is at (2, 7).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{ 0})$ and $B(\greenD{6}, \blueD{0})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{6}-\greenD{2}&=4\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $4$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{ 0})$ and $D(\greenD{2}, \blueD{7})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{7}-\blueD{0}&=7\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $7$ units.
Now we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width}  \\\\ \text{Area} &=4\times 7 \\\\ \text{Area} &= 28 \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $28$ square units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(-4, -2)$, $B(-2, -2)$, $C(-2, 7)$, and $D(-4, 7)$.    **What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**   square units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (negative 4, negative 2). Vertex B is at (negative 2, negative 2). Vertex C is at (negative 2, 7). Vertex D is at (negative 4, 7).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{-4},\blueD{ -2})$ and $B(\greenD{-2}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{-2}-(\greenD{-4})&=2\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-4},\blueD{ -2})$ and $D(\greenD{-4}, \blueD{7})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{7}-(\blueD{-2})&=9\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $9$ units.
Now we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width}  \\\\ \text{Area} &=2\times 9 \\\\ \text{Area} &= 18 \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $18$ square units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(-8, 3)$, $B(-3, 3)$, $C(-3, 6)$, and $D(-8, 6)$.    **What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**   square units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (negative 8, 3). Vertex B is at (negative 3, 3). Vertex C is at (negative 3, 6). Vertex D is at (negative 8, 6).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{-8},\blueD{ 3})$ and $B(\greenD{-3}, \blueD{3})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{-3}-(\greenD{-8})&=5\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $5$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-8},\blueD{ 3})$ and $D(\greenD{-8}, \blueD{6})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{6}-\blueD{3}&=3\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $3$ units.
Now we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width}  \\\\ \text{Area} &=5\times 3 \\\\ \text{Area} &= 15 \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $15$ square units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(-2, 2)$, $B(6, 2)$, $C(6, 3)$, and $D(-2, 3)$.    **What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**   square units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (negative 2, 2). Vertex B is at (6, 2). Vertex C is at (6, 3). Vertex D is at (negative 2, 3).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{ 2})$ and $B(\greenD{6}, \blueD{2})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{6}-(\greenD{-2})&=8\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $8$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{ 2})$ and $D(\greenD{-2}, \blueD{3})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{3}-\blueD{2}&=1\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $1$ units.
Now we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width}  \\\\ \text{Area} &=8\times 1 \\\\ \text{Area} &= 8 \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $8$ square units.

question.content: Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle: $A(3, -2)$, $B(6, -2)$, $C(6, 5)$, and $D(3, 5)$.    **What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**   square units

hints.content: Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle is on the coordinate plane. The coordinate grid is labeled from negative 10 to 10 from the origin in both the x and y axis. Vertex A is at (3, negative 2). Vertex B is at (6, negative 2). Vertex C is at (6, 5). Vertex D is at (3, 5).

hints.content: Since $A(\greenD{3},\blueD{ -2})$ and $B(\greenD{6}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{6}-\greenD{3}&=3\end{align}$     Side $AB$ had a length of $3$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{3},\blueD{ -2})$ and $D(\greenD{3}, \blueD{5})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a vertical line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:    $\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{5}-(\blueD{-2})&=7\end{align}$    Side $AD$ had a length of $7$ units.
Now we can find the area.   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width}  \\\\ \text{Area} &=3\times 7 \\\\ \text{Area} &= 21 \end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $21$ square units.
